title: Smoked Pork Butt Recipe
description: This smoked pork butt recipe can be done with a brined or unbrined pork butt roast. The pork is tender and smoky — perfect for BBQ pork sandwiches.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Main Dishes Pork Pulled Pork Smoked Pork Butt 4.4 (56) 45 Reviews 11 Photos We make this smoked pork butt recipe every few weeks because we love pulled BBQ pork sandwiches. The pork just shreds apart after it's done, and the smoky flavor is incredible. It's best to brine the meat overnight to help it retain moisture during smoking, but it's not necessary. Serve the shredded pork on buns with your favorite sauce. It's an authentic pit barbecue right in your own house! Submitted by Smokin' Ron Updated on August 26, 2024 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 11 11 11 11 Prep Time: 25 mins Cook Time: 6 hrs Additional Time: 30 mins Total Time: 6 hrs 55 mins Servings: 16 Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Original recipe (1X) yields 16 servings 4 tablespoons packed brown sugar 2 tablespoons ground New Mexico chili powder 7 pounds fresh pork butt roast Directions Gather all ingredients. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios If desired, soak the pork butt in a brine solution for at least 4 hours or overnight. There's a recipe for a brine on this site titled 'Basic Brine for Smoking Meat'. You should do this covered and in the refrigerator. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Preheat an outdoor smoker for 200 to 225 degrees F (95 to 110 degrees C). Place a roasting rack in a drip pan. While grill preheats, in a small bowl, combine the brown sugar, chili powder and any additional seasonings to your taste. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Apply this liberally to the meat and rub it in with your fingers.  Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Place a roasting rack in a drip pan and lay the meat on the rack. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Smoke at 200 to 225°F (95 to 110°C) for 6 to 18 hours, or until internal pork temperature reaches 145°F (63°C). Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Cook’s Note If desired, you can brine your pork roast before smoking it. Try my Basic Brine for Smoking Meat, and soak pork in brine in a food-grade, non-reactive container, covered in the refrigerator, for at least 4 hours or overnight. I like to rub pork with a very spicy dry rub before I smoke it. I usually make up it each time, so it's always different. You can add additional seasonings to your dry rub as desired. For more flavor, add wood chips to your smoker. I use apple wood chips because we like the sweet, fruity flavor they give the pork. I Made It Print 87 home cooks made it! Add Your Photo Photos of Smoked Pork Butt 01 of 11 Photo by  Dotdash Meredith Food Studios 02 of 11 Photo by  Anthony Silva 08/27/2019 03 of 11 Photo by  Sindi Speegle Brelsford 07/20/2019 04 of 11 Photo by  John Cargill 02/12/2017 Made it for the Super Bowl, had to speed the cooking time due to my lack of being prepared so it didn't pull quite as nice as I wanted (this was my fault, not the recipe). It was delicious and I received tons of compliments, even heard a "best I ever had". I added just a little Cajun seasoning and pork producers seasoning to the rub. Great recipe, great instructions. Thanks. 05 of 11 Photo by  HonestDish1975 05/30/2015 06 of 11 Photo by  BrianPav 06/01/2014 I smoked a 8.5lb pork shoulder yesterday and it was fantastic! I did use the basic brine instructions and it soaked over night prior to smoking. I did a few deviations from the recipe per the comments of others. One was that I used Big James' Pork Rub (which you can search on here). I smoked for 9hrs maintaining 200-220F, but I did wrap in foil half way through. And finally I cooked it with the fat side up. After 9hrs, I pulled it off and let it rest for 20-30mim. Results: "fall off the bone", juiciest, tastiest pork shoulder I ever had. I served a party of 12 and it was plenty. People raved about it all night. What a great feeling! 07 of 11 Photo by  Marie Smith 06/15/2012 08 of 11 Photo by  cbrown370 08/21/2010 09 of 11 Photo by  abapplez 06/13/2010 10 of 11 Photo by  Art71 06/01/2010 Tried this for Memorial Day and was only my second attempt at smoking anything... I followed the instructions to the letter and did soak overnight in the brine. It came out fantastic and everyone loved it. The smoke ring was impressive too (see added photo). I could have let this go longer if I wasn't timing it for a dinner with guests but it was fabulous as is. If I were to do it again I would let it get a little higher than the 170 degrees I pulled it at. I would have let it go to 185 to pull apart easier.
